There is one exception that I wish to pursue, not solely because of the person it comes from, although the person it comes from holds a special position in relation to the Parliament. That person raised an important matter which was pursued at the Estimates Committee C proceedings and which should be pursued a little further. That person sent me a letter which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Isn't something going to be done about Wendy McCarthy being permitted to draw a salary from the Australian Bicentennial Authority while at the same time being paid a stipend as Deputy Chairman of the Corporation? I find it astonishing that no one appearing before your Committee could say what she receives by way of stipend from the Corporation.

What on earth were those fifteen officers doing in Canberra if they didn't know more than they claimed? Why didn't Mr Whitehead appear before the Committee personally if his Staff are so bereft of information?

That letter came from the Hon. Clyde Cameron, AO. It is a fairly lengthy letter, and it relates to a cross-section of matters which arose from his reading of the Hansard of the Committee's proceedings. The question he has raised is a question which a number of other people have raised. Is it reasonable that someone who, judging from an answer to a question asked by Senator Peter Baume, appears to be receiving a Remuneration Tribunal allowance of $13,564 per annum as Deputy Chairman of the ABC-I have a document here which shows that amount is paid to Wendy McCarthy as Deputy Chairman-should also receive payment as a full time member of the Australian Bicentennial Authority? Does the Bicentennial Authority expect its officers to devote their full time and attention to the duties to which they were appointed? Since she was appointed to the Bicentennial Authority, has she devoted any time during normal office hours to ABC business? If she has devoted any time to ABC business has she been given special leave by the Bicentennial Authority? If so, has her salary been adjusted downwards accordingly? Many of these sorts of questions have been raised in correspondence sent to me. I have summarised them by reading the questions raised in the letter from the Hon. Clyde Cameron.

TALK.START.PARA: —The facts as Senator Peter Rae puts them are correct, although I understand he has overstated, or Clyde Cameron has overstated, the number of officials who were present at the Estimates Committee hearing. I understand that the answer given at the Estimates Committee hearing was that Wendy McCarthy did get a stipend and that the officers present would find out how much she got. That question has been answered. The Bicentennial Authority is a company limited by guarantee which is composed of State and Federal elements. When Ms McCarthy, who, I must admit, seems to have raised great interest amongst Opposition Senators, was to be employed by that Authority, she raised the matter of her remuneration from the ABC with the Authority. As I understand it, the Authority raised it with the Public Service Board. As a result we have the situation which exists now. In the light of what Senator Peter Rae has said, I wonder what is the difference between someone who is employed in a private, legally limited company, who receives a similar stipend from the ABC, and Ms McCarthy. Is it just that the Opposition has a hang-up about Ms McCarthy?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have a hang-up about anybody in particular in the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, nor do I have a hang-up about the Corporation itself. I am asking questions about the administration of a Commonwealth statutory authority which has a budget of almost $400m a year and about which there is considerable public interest, as evidenced by the huge number of letters, questions and media items we have seen. Ms McCarthy's potential conflict of interest as a Board member and as an author, as a journalist for the magazine Look and Listen, who receives a salary for writing about what happens on the Board of the ABC, has been the subject of some attention; she is employed by what appear to be two publicly funded bodies which receive considerable public attention-that is, the ABC and the Australian Bicentennial Authority. She has been the subject of much correspondence. Mr Jackson of the ABC was the author of one of the letters defending Ms McCarthy. All of those things have drawn attention to the matters I am pursuing. Were I to pursue every one of these matters I would take a very long time. I have tried to be selective in regard to the matters raised in the correspondence. I proposed to do no more than ask about four matters, and potential conflicts of interest in dual roles is one of them. I have summarised that as briefly as I can using, in particular, the example of Ms McCarthy. Perhaps the Minister would indicate whether there is anything in the answers provided relating to the potential conflict of interest of a journalist, who is also a Board member of the ABC, being employed and paid by Look and Listen, which is funded under a special arrangement by the ABC, to write repeatedly for issues of that magazine about what happens in regard to the Board. It has been described to me as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: It is therefore inescapable that Ms McCarthy derived income from writing about ABC affairs with the distinct advantage of inside knowledge derived from her appointment to the Board for which she was separately remunerated.
This letter I have received further states:

Ms McCarthy wrote about major issues of policy and practice in her columns, e.g. the appointment of the Managing Director and other senior staff (October 1984 edition) and the achievements of the first year of the Board (August 1984 edition) and the corporate advertising campaign (January 1985 edition).
Does the Government or the ABC see any conflict of interest in this situation?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Rae knows that Look and Listen is published by the David Burton publishing company and that it pays royalties to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. Ms McCarthy was commissioned by the then editor of the magazine and, as the answer says, was paid at the standard page rate for writing reflective articles on the ABC. She no longer contributes to the magazine and notified the Board in advance of her decision. It is easy enough for Senator Rae to suggest that this is a great conflict of interest. Maybe it was and maybe it was not wise for Ms McCarthy, as a journalist, to do this, but as Senator Rae said, we are talking about an organisation which has a budget of around $400m, so we are not talking about small bikkies in this instance. Even though it is important to all of us that we do not have a conflict of interest, I would have thought that it was drawing a very long bow to make a great issue of this matter at this time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did refer to a number of other potential conflicts of interest during Estimates Committee C proceedings. Answers have been given. Perhaps between now and the next Estimates Committee hearings some consideration could be given to whether there are or are not conflicts of interest in the matters I have raised and whether a policy statement should be made publicly available on what constitutes a conflict of interest in contracts between members of the Board and the ABC for the provision of a variety of services, either directly or indirectly, for example in relation to films. I take it no further than that at the moment; I simply extend that request and hope that it may be taken into account.

SPEECH.PARA: The next matter I wish to refer to-I will be as brief as I can in relation to this-is the Special Broadcasting Service's recent advertisement for an executive director. The position was widely advertised, and among other things the advertisement contained the statement:

To be eligible for appointment applications must be Australian citizens, however applicants who have permanent resident status may be offered fixed-term employment pending the granting of citizenship.

It is noticeable that these conditions applying to the position of SBS Executive Director and the other recently advertised job with the SBS, that of Director of News and Current Affairs, are not conditions which apply to the very senior positions at the ABC-for instance, the Managing Director and the Director of Television News and Current Affairs. Is there any Government policy in relation to this? Is it considered that the nation's multicultural channels require Australians at the helm but the nation's broadcasting service does not? I further ask: Has there been any change of policy since the appointment of the present senior officers of the ABC including the Managing Director? If that position is readvertised, perhaps because of the present Managing Director walking under the proverbial bus, would there be a similar requirement to that applying to positions in the Special Broadcasting Service; that is, that the applicant must be an Australian citizen, though a non-citizen might under special circumstances be offered fixed term employment pending the granting of citizenship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Employment within the SBS comes under the Public Service Act, therefore under the provision that applicants be citizens or that successful applicants be contracted for jobs pending citizenship. The ABC is not in that situation. The ABC Board, in its wisdom, tried to get the best person for the job-as I dare say the New Zealand Broadcasting Corporation did when it got the same person. The vast majority of jobs in the ABC in fact go to Australian citizens. Only a few jobs have gone to people who are not Australian citizens and because they have been high level jobs it has caused a bit of a furore. Although I am not supposed to give personal views, I think it is an extreme example of chauvinism to suggest that we should limit employment in sensitive jobs purely to Australian citizens. I thought we would be after the best person for the job. Whether or not in the view of Senator Rae, me or anyone else the person selected is the best person for the job is a matter for judgment. I would have thought that to hamstring the ABC in the way suggested by Senator Rae would be a bit silly.

SPEECH.PARA: As to the remarks about Ms McCarthy and others, I will certainly seek from the ABC and the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) an answer to the questions on policy. I think it is important that we do have such answers. It is equally important that senators, in asking questions in Estimates committees, do not make imputations about people, such as the claim that Ms McCarthy's books were sold in the ABC bookshops and that she was getting royalties from that through the ABC. It could have been easily determined to be false, but it was thrown into the questions obviously in an attempt to discredit Ms McCarthy and the ABC. If we on this side are going to be responsible, I think there is an obligation for those on the other side to be responsible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to that, there was one apparent error in about 40 specific examples given. I do not think that is bad. If the honourable senator could be as accurate, I think he would be doing quite well.
—That would be very easy to check, but you obviously did not bother.

—The information given to me was that the books were in the bookshop. I had not personally been to check that. Perhaps, after this, I will make a personal check, and do a double check as to the information which is provided to me. However, I find that that is a rather cheapskate sort of remark not really deserving of the nature of the debate which has taken place and which I have been trying to keep on a proper level.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to another matter, the thirtieth anniversary of the Bandung Conference in Indonesia and the efficiency or otherwise with which the Australian Broadcasting Corporation is now able to organise the co-ordination at an editorial level of the coverage of events. What mechanism is there in the ABC for the co-ordination at an editorial level of the coverage of events, both at home and overseas, by different elements of the ABC, especially between television and radio and between separate elements within each medium, bearing in mind that apparently for the not exactly world spectacular thirtieth anniversary of the Bandung Conference the ABC had about nine members of staff representing four different program outlets present, all I think, travelling to Indonesia to cover events? Certainly there were some from Singapore and some from Australia. What has been done under the restructuring of the ABC which, as I understood it from what had previously been said by the Managing Director, was to be the media split of the organisation between the television and radio divisions to make the ABC 'more streamlined and efficient'? I wonder whether having nine people representing four different program outlets at the conference, most of them travelling very considerable distances at considerable cost, is an example of streamlining and efficiency?

TALK.START.PARA: —To show that I can be charitable, Senator, I will say that it does not seem to me on the face of it to be very satisfactory that so many different groups from the one organisation should go to such a conference-although I suggest that there is a very great difference between Four Corners and ABC radio and ABC television, if they were there. I understand that under the new arrangements there is more co-operation than there has been in the past. I hope that co-operation continues; but as this is not within my area of expertise, I cannot give any guarantees.

—I wonder whether the Minister could ask the ABC to give a more detailed answer to that question as to what is happening with regard to the mechanisms for co-ordination at an editorial level of the coverage of events. Perhaps some information could be given in writing at a later stage.
—I will refer that to the ABC.
—Thank you, Senator.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Since the National has been in progress, for some weeks, I have received two complaints about the National-which I would not say is a very high number. I have had about 25 complaints, not in an orchestrated way, about the cancelling of the football replay on Saturday nights. Honourable senators from other States may laugh, but they do not realise the seriousness of this. As Channel 2 can no longer broadcast the programs on Saturday nights at 6.30, through pressure from the Victorian Football League and Channel 7, many people in country areas get no coverage because the commercial channels in country areas pick up the replays very late when people are already in bed. The 6.30 p.m. program, uninterrupted by advertisements, was extremely popular in country areas. For those who live in the city and like going out to restaurants it was also very good, because they could watch the half hour and then go out.

SPEECH.PARA: It appears that the main reason for not putting the program on is lack of finance to be able to compete with a commercial channel. I know that this is an old and difficult story with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. In this case, however, I would have thought that if we could lop $1m off the $30m-a-year budget of the National, a program which apparently very few people in Victoria watch, and put it into financing the football replay, that would be very much appreciated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Robert Ray may or may not be surprised, but I am informed that the ratings of the National have actually increased considerably recently. I am also informed that the cost of the National, compared with that of what it replaced, is in fact only a matter of $1m here and $1m there. As to the VFL and football replay, I suppose it depends on one's views. As an ex-New South Welshman and a player of that vulgar game rugby league, I am always very pleased with the ABC because I can watch the Sydney rugby league on a Saturday afternoon. I feel very badly about country people missing out on the VFL. I will refer that matter to the ABC to see whether it can be corrected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge that the National has changed both its format and its ratings. Perhaps some good came out of what otherwise might have been seen as some undue publicity received by the National. From some of the comments which have been received, it would seem that there is some room to go, but the program is certainly improving its acceptance ratings.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to page 3 of the answers given by way of information in which a response refers to pages 116 and 117 of the Hansard of the Estimates Committee in which I asked about details of cuts of $8m and $30m which Mr Whitehead claimed he had effected to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's budget. That claim was made in an interview. The answer is:

The cuts referred to were related to proposals made by ABC departments and divisions which were rejected or considerably pruned by the Managing Director before submission to the ABC Board. It is not unusual, though perhaps not technically accurate, to refer to such reductions as savings. In the broadcast interview which was extemporaneous and live to air, Mr Whitehead was speaking in the context of accountability at all levels of the ABC and giving examples of the need to examine critically all proposals for expenditure.

I suppose one can only say: 'There we go again'. This is almost similar to the mini-Budget debate, as to what constitutes a cut and what constitutes the normal reductions which take place in the preliminary bids. Is my understanding correct that Mr Whitehead was really not strictly accurate in saying that he made cuts of $8m and $30m during his first period as Managing Director, but rather that in the assessment of proposals which were made, in putting them to the Board, he pruned them before they went to the Board? In other words, this was not committed expenditure which was cut, but rather proposals for expenditure which were pruned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose that that is right, Senator. I suppose the answer is that if Mr Whitehead had not been there to prune those proposals, on past record they would have gone through. I think he is trying to modernise the ABC and its procedures. To do that he had to hack around at some of its proposals, and he did so. Whether it is reasonable to call those proposals cuts is, I suppose, a matter for conjecture. However, I think the intent and the meaning is clear, now that the extra answer has been given.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —So that we may understand the nature of the claims that were being made by Mr Whitehead and the answer that has been given, could some broad summary be given in writing at a later stage of what was contained in the $8m and $30m cuts?
—Yes.
—I thank the Minister. I wish now to refer to page 14 of the further additional information which has been provided and which begins with the question:

SPEECH.PARA: Concerning the ABC, at what percentage rate is the latest actuarial requirement for employer's contribution.
This referred to superannuation. The answer was:

. . . the Department of Finance . . . advised that three actuarial reports have yet to be completed by the Actuary and it is not expected that an announcement will be made until those reports have been considered.
I am unclear as to why there are three actuarial reports. Can the Minister explain? I will then ask a further question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not really paying attention but I think what Senator Rae was referring to was the review of contributions to the Commonwealth superannuation scheme for coverage of statutory authority employees by that scheme.

—I was referring to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. I am glad that the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, is here. Perhaps he will be able to answer my question. What is the percentage rate which is the latest actuarial requirement for the ABC contribution, as an employer, to the Commonwealth superannuation scheme? It is my understanding that contributions are actuarially calculated in respect of each of the statutory authorities; that they are not identical and that there is considerable variation between them. What I want to know now is this: Firstly, what is the current requirement for the ABC? Secondly, what is meant by the answer which mentioned awaiting three actuarial reports?
—I do not know off the top of my head what the present ABC contribution is. Nobody here does. There are no Department of Finance officials here who might know the answer.
—Could it be provided in writing?

—Yes. I am not sure off the top of my head but I think that the answer must refer to three statutory authorities and the total under review. I do not know which three statutory authorities they are. Senator Peter Rae is correct in saying that the present contributions, and the likely future contributions, from statutory authorities will not be identical because they are to be actuarially assessed within the authority. From memory, there are variations in contribution rates of about 15 to 21 per cent at present.
—And even more than that.

—And possibly even more than that. As I understand it, Senator Rae is interested in knowing what the present rate of contribution is for the ABC and where the revision of that rate, if any, now stands.
—Yes.
—Senator Rae has indicated that that is what he wants. I will try to get that information for him as soon as possible. It may be possible to get it before the adjournment tonight.

—I thank the Minister. I would like to ask just one further question. The other aspect of superannuation that I wanted to ask about is that relating to the Special Broadcasting Service. Because there were problems with the legislation relating to the SBS and the government of the day decided that it would avoid the Parliament, not bother about the legislation and create the body anyway, the SBS was not created as a statutory authority. Consequently, it does not make an employer's contribution to superannuation for its employees. However, if one were to try to make a comparison of costs with public broadcasting, one would need to calculate what would be the employer's contribution were the SBS a statutory authority. What I would like to ask is whether that information is available and, if it is not available, whether it could be made available; that is, on the supposition that the SBS was a statutory authority, which it would have been, and on the same basis as the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. On that basis, what would the employer's contribution to the Commonwealth be?

—I could not give a precise answer and I understand it would be very difficult to get one. But a rule of thumb is that contribution rates for statutory authorities are usually of the order of 20 per cent of salaries. Assuming that all Special Broadcasting Service employees were members of the Commonwealth superannuation scheme and were all on salaries and not paid under contract, the notional figure for which Senator Peter Rae is looking would be about 20 per cent of salaries. I will see whether any further information is available but the indications are that it would be very difficult to get it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It appears that this is the appropriate time to refer to the decision of the Board of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation to extend entitlements, including relocation expenses and privileges appropriate to spouses and families of staff, to homosexual partners of ABC staff. In the hearings of Estimates Committee A on 4 September 1984, the Managing Director of the ABC indicated that the Board's decision was based on anti-discrimination legislation, that is to say, on an assumption of legal responsibility, and on the fact that the practice had been adopted by corporations. We assume that that meant outside corporations. The statements made by the Managing Director at that time both on that matter and on a number of other matters were referred to in the report of Estimates Committee A which considered that the responses were less than adequate. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Additional information sought at the September hearing, while this time received promptly, was again considered by the Committee to be less than adequate.
At the hearing itself the Committee considered as less than satisfactory a number of the answers given by Mr Whitehead . . .

At the recent Estimates Committee's hearings on 15 April 1985 it transpired that the assumption of legal responsibility was in fact a myth; it was admitted to have been a myth and, therefore, the Committee was misled on 4 September 1984.

The other basis for the Board's decision, as given to us previously, was that corporations had similar guidelines. It appears from the letters that have been subsequently received by Estimates Committee C that that also is a myth and has no basis whatsoever. A decision was taken by the Board of a public corporation on a matter of very major public importance. It was stated that the decision was based on an assumption of legal responsibility which was found to be non-existent. A statement was provided by the Board that this was a regular practice in other corporations which was found not to be the case. I feel that it is important that the chamber is apprised of this matter. In my view it then raises for question-obviously it cannot be dealt with in the Committee stage-the need for a review of that decision by the Board, given that the basis for that decision was and has now been found to be non-existent.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the past 18 months have any real property valuations been carried out either in Sydney or elsewhere on the eastern seaboard of Australia of property owned or contemplated for purchase by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation? If so, by whom were those valuations carried out and of what properties?

—I am informed that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation is, at the moment, trying to get accurate valuations of all its assets. These valuations are done by the valuers in the Australian Taxation Office.

— My understanding is that the Minister for Community Services (Senator Grimes) said that real property valuations, as well as other valuations, are done by the Australian Taxation Office. I just want to check whether my understanding is correct.
—Property valuations are carried out by the Australian Taxation Office. There are private valuers for other valuations. But all property valuations are carried out by the Taxation Office.

— Am I correct in understanding that a 15 per cent salary loading applies to staff of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation who have to start work before 6 a.m.? Do some staff commence work at 5.56 a.m., four minutes before 6 a.m., and receive the 15 per cent loading for the whole of the time that they are on duty? That allegation has been raised with me both specifically and generally. Is it accurate? If so, can something be done, in some practical way, to effect what might amount to a quite substantial saving?
—No one here can vouch for the accuracy or otherwise of that statement. It is certainly a question worth raising. If it is true, it is something worth doing something about.

—The next matter to which I refer is program policy development. Apparently there is some controversy as to whether there should be program policy development as part of the overall corporate planning program of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. What is happening in relation to that program policy? Is it being developed in writing? If so, will it be published?
—I am informed that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's corporate planning program is just about complete. It is to be published. It will be made public in June or July.
—Will a program policy development component be included in the corporate plan? If so, will it be published?
—My answer to Senator Peter Rae is yes; it is an important part of the corporate plan.

—The next matter to which I would like to refer is the major corporate advertising program which was undertaken by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation of which everybody would be aware. The information I seek may not be readily available but may have to be obtained. I ask: Firstly, what was the cost of the corporate advertising program? Secondly, has any analysis been undertaken of the cost benefit of that program? I realise that an analysis of the cost benefit is difficult, nevertheless, it is undertaken in relation to advertising programs.
—I will certainly have to take both those questions on notice.

—Have any advertising agents been engaged within the past two years by the Australian Broadcasting Corporation? If so, were those advertising agents or consultants chosen as a result of tenders being called?
—Yes, advertising agencies were employed. The advertising agency was Ogilvy and Mather (Australia) Pty Ltd. Tenders were not called.
—If tenders were not called, when was Ogilvy and Mather (Australia) Pty Ltd engaged? By whom was the company engaged? Why were tenders not called? How was the price negotiated?
—I will certainly take those questions on notice.

—I conclude by thanking the Minister for his assistance in answering my many questions. I just said to my colleague Senator Peter Baume that the material I have in front of me is enough to have kept me going for another two or three days. I realise that we do not have the time for that. I make that indication to give some idea of the amount of interest shown and the inflow of information available to anyone who shows any interest in the affairs of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. Whoever is in government and whoever is managing the ABC should anticipate that when matters come before the Senate and Senate committees there will continue to be a lot of material upon which questions are asked. I have done an edit job and have shortened my questions as much as I could. I have raised a few cross-section examples, but there are a lot more that I have not raised.

—I thank Senator Peter Rae for his warning. I will not be around next time. Last night Senator Rae referred to a discussion on 13 February 1985 between a number of Australian Broadcasting Corporation Board members. He pointed out that the Chairman of the Board was not present at the meeting, which is apparently in conflict with other advice that the Chairman was present at all meetings of the Board. As I said last night, members of the ABC Board did confer on 13 February 1985. This was not regarded as a meeting of the Board for the purposes of section 22 of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983 since it did not comply with many of the formal requirements of that section. The matters discussed were confirmed at the next formal meeting of the Board, at which the Chairman was present. Last night Senator Peter Rae also-
—Ha, ha!
—I think even Senator Puplick would realise that that has been known to happen even in political parties as well as on the ABC Board.
—It usually results in pre-selections being overturned.
—Yes, that is right.
—If it is announced, that is fair enough. If it is not, it does not help those who ask questions.

—That it true; I accept that. Senator Rae last night also referred to a letter dated 7 February 1985 from the Auditor-General to the Chief General Manager of the Australian Postal Commission concerning an efficiency audit of the administration of counter services. Senator Rae asked for details of the comments made in the Chief General Manager's letter of 4 July 1984 as referred to in the penultimate paragraph of the Auditor-General's letter. In response to that question I table a copy of the letter of 4 July to the Auditor-General from the Chief General Manager of the Australian Postal Commission. It is several pages long.

—I thank the Minister for the replies he has given. I raise with him only two matters. One is the possibility that I might wish to ask a question after I have had a chance to see the letter of 4 July. Secondly, the Minister said that a meeting which was not formal within the meaning of the Act took place on 13 February and that the decision taken was confirmed at a later meeting. The information provided to us was that there were meetings on 13 and 14 February and that a Board decision was taken. In order to clarify this once and for all, can the Minister tell me whether the decision that was confirmed was the decision taken on 13 February or the decision taken on 14 February, and when was the decision confirmed by the Board?
—The answer I have is that the original meeting was held on 13 February. I have no reference to 14 February here.
—It is in the explanatory notes.
—It was confirmed at the next formal meeting of the Board. When that meeting took place I do not know, but we will look up the diary to find out.
—Perhaps the actual minute confirming it could be provided.
—I am surprised that you do not have it.
—It is about the only thing I have not got.
—I am told that the next meeting was on 28 February.
—I thank the Minister and I would be obliged if we could have the detail of the minute confirming the decision that was taken provided in writing as soon as possible.
—Yes, that will be provided.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.
